LanguageData.AEXP_Gorilla.label: gorilla
LanguageData.AEXP_Gorilla.description: These ground-dwelling herbivorous apes are the largest living primates, and they are the next closest living relatives to humans after the chimpanzees and bonobos. Like all the great apes, the arms of the gorilla are longer than its legs. Gorillas are usually surprisingly shy, though they may show aggression by beating their chests and charging if their social group is threatened.

LanguageData.AEXP_Jaguar.label: jaguar
LanguageData.AEXP_Jaguar.description: A large felid species and the only existing member of the Panthera native to the Americas in old Earth. This spotted cat closely resembles the leopard, but is usually larger and sturdier. The jaguar enjoys swimming and is largely a solitary, opportunistic, stalk-and-ambush predator at the top of the food chain.
LanguageData.AEXP_Lemur.label: lemur
LanguageData.AEXP_Lemur.description: A small primate, lemurs are arboreal, and usually nocturnal. They have a pointed snout, large eyes, and a long tail. Although they are social creatures, they have traditionally been regarded as being less intelligent than other primates, since they don't exhibit behaviours of tool use in the wild.

LanguageData.AEXP_Mandrill.label: mandrill
LanguageData.AEXP_Mandrill.description: Mandrills are one of the largest of all monkeys. They are shy and reclusive primates that live only in rain forests. Mandrills are extremely colorful, perhaps more so than any other mammal. They are easily identifiable by the blue and red skin on their faces and their brightly hued rumps.

LanguageData.AEXP_Tapir.label: tapir
LanguageData.AEXP_Tapir.description: A large, herbivorous mammal, similar in shape to a pig, with a short nose trunk, tapirs inhabit jungle and forest regions.

LanguageData.AEXP_Tiger.label: tiger
LanguageData.AEXP_Tiger.description: The tiger is the largest species among the big cats. It is most recognisable for its dark vertical stripes on reddish-orange fur with a lighter underside. It is an apex predator, territorial and generally solitary. In the wild, tigers mostly feed on large and medium-sized mammals.
